content_scrubbed:
as a woman on the academic job market in the humanities who[.] still trying to find her professional style, i feel like i have to respond to this article. an important factor in this woman[.] experience is the fact that she speaks as a graduate student who occupies a liminal space: alternately teacher and student, not a professor but not an undergraduate. it[.] a difficult space to occupy, especially when teaching discussion sections early on in one[.] respective programs. how *are* you supposed to dress? is there any way to get students to see you as an authority figure and not just as an assistant to the "real" teacher? 

when i started grad school i also dressed up to teach--dresses, heels, makeup, etc--but quickly realized that no amount of styling was going to get students, colleagues, or professors to respect me. i'm a petite pixie-haired young-looking grad student. i had to command that respect on my own, and i couldn't do it while feeling uncomfortable. so i started wearing what i find comfortable: dark jeans, Dr. Martens and Fluevogs (yes you *can* wear Fluevogs), sweaters, etc. i'm clean, i'm put-together, i wear a little makeup, and i also feel like me. i own myself and i know my shit so i feel much better about walking into a classroom now than i did four or five years ago. but i also have the privilege of being petite, white, cisgender, no "visible" disabilities, native english speaker, etc so the likelihood someone would make a comment critical of my appearance is low already.

it is also absolutely true that every department, school, and discipline is different. i am at a school in the pacific northwest, so what i "get away with" is much different than it is for other people. even my interview outfits i am putting together are probably much more artsy and slightly more casual than someone in STEM or business or law or whatever, or even someone in the humanities on the east coast. i'm still keeping my tattoos covered but i'm sure at some places a bunch of colleagues would have them, and at other places they would be totally taboo. 

change is slow and sexism exists and it sucks sometimes, and that[.] something that Kelsky mentions in her book (the on the market grad student bible). she gives advice on interview attire that is basically wear what you normally wear, but nicer/better/cleaner/fancier. if that means you're a ["butch dyke"](http://theprofessorisin. com/2011/11/07/how-to-dress-for-an-interview-as-a-butch-dyke/) (her words, check out the article) who wears men[.] clothing, do that but fancier. looking uncomfortable and feeling uncomfortable are terrible in job interviews, which are awkward and nerve-wracking enough already. so if that means keeping your nose ring or pink hair or heels or red lipstick or flouncy skirts or whatever, do that thing. just own it, and know that not everyone is going to be ok with it, but hopefully your scholarship, personality, and confidence will show them that your aesthetic is an organic part of you that makes you the academic you are.
